definition:
A *directed set* is a partially ordered set $(A, \leq)$ such that
whenever $a,b\in A$ there is an $x\in A$ such that $a\leq x$ and
$b\leq x$.

A subset $B\subseteq A$ is said to be *residual* if there is $a\in A$
such that $b\in B$ whenever $a\leq b$, and *cofinal* if for each
$a\in A$ there is $b\in B$ such that $a\leq b$.

A directed set is sometimes called an *upward-directed set*. We may also
define the dual notion: a *downward-directed set* (or *filtered set*) is
a partially ordered set $(A, \leq)$ such that whenever $a,b\in A$ there
is an $x\in A$ such that $x\leq a$ and $x\leq b$.

Note: Many authors do not require $\leq$ to be antisymmetric, so that it
is only a pre-order (rather than a partial order) with the given
property. Also, it is common to require $A$ to be non-empty.
